texts.definition: Game elements or information that instruct players how goals can be fulfilled.
markups: <style="Definition">Game elements or information that instruct players how goals can be fulfilled.</style>

Players may be unsure about how to fulfill goals in games for several reasons. They may have misunderstood the descriptions provided, they may know what the goals are but not how to reach them, or the games may be designed so figuring out what the goals are is part of the gameplay. <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> are game elements or information that players can find through gameplay that helps them become aware of what the goals actually are. The <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> may be explicit, describing exactly how to reach the goal, or implicit, describing facts and events in the game world which need to be interpreted by the players. Of course, this categorization is not clear-cut, as the vagueness of the clues can vary.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

<style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda%20series">The Legend of Zelda series</link></style> often provide players with tips about how to not only play the game but how the interface works. The series also makes uses of signs in the environment to show where different locations are; this design solution is also present in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style>. Signs are also used in most racing games, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gran%20Turismo%20series">Gran Turismo series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Need%20for%20Speed%20series">Need for Speed series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sega%20Rally%20series">Sega Rally series</link></style>, to contain warnings about upcoming curves.

In the board game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mansions%20of%20Madness">Mansions of Madness</link></style>, game masters place a sequence of cards representing <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> that help players finding out how to win the scenarios they are playing.

The location of quests in both the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style> and the latter installments of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> are marked on maps, and for the latter the direction to this locations are indicated  in the HUD compass.
Good locations to place portals in Portal 2 are marked with crosshairs in some of the more challenging levels.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

Besides what information they should include, designing <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> requires an awareness of why the information should be provided and how it should be provided. Generally, <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> are typically introduced to modulate how difficult <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> should be or to ensure <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style>. However, <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> may not necessarily lead players towards actions they perceive as beneficial for the progress in the game. When this is the case, <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> are instead used to promote actions, which the players would probably not otherwise initiate, in order to support <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. This may be make these <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> examples of the <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style> pattern, used to trick players into actions that are against their low-level goals but that may be required to complete the telling of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> or to put the players in positions so that they can reach the higher-level goals of the game. <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> to finding <style="Link"><link="easter-eggs">Easter Eggs</link></style> are examples of luring players to perform actions that are not necessarily required to complete or win games, and can be seen as <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> to finishing <style="Link"><link="unknown-goals">Unknown Goals</link></style>. So are those leading to <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style> in general, but these may provide <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> that can help indirectly towards finishing game goals.

Looking at how they are presented, <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> either take the form of information purely about games' <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Realities</link></style> or information that breaks <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> through containing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style>. Regardless, <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> can be designed to take the form of advices, encouragements, or warnings. Advices tell players what to do before they have started performing a set of actions; encouragements provide feedback that a given action is correct although the goal or the closure is not completed yet; and warnings give players advice on what not to do. Encouragements are typically used to indicate completion of low-level subgoals in <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style> or to promote further <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> of a given area or object. A more specific type of encouragements are <style="Link"><link="near-miss-indicators">Near Miss Indicators</link></style> - these indicate that players have tried performing correct actions but failed to do them correctly.

<style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> can be created in many ways. They can be game elements in games that have to be interacted with to reveal information, e.g. <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style>, or simply properties of the environment, e.g. <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>. These types of <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> may however be impossible to actually detect unless the correct <style="Link"><link="vision-modes">Vision Modes</link></style> are used; <style="Link"><link="point-interest-indicators">Point of Interest Indicators</link></style> in contrast can provide extra attention to <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> that might have been found anyway. By using game elements together, <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style> can be created which also can function as <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eavesdropping">Eavesdropping</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> are ways in which <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> can be achieved socially through interaction with <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> (or <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style>). <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> can also be provided in as <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Automated%20Responses">Automated Responses</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> can be used to minimize the risk of players missing the information presentations in the <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style>, and these can either be the actual <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> or ways of pointing players to the game elements or <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> that are the <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style>. <style="Link"><link="player-aids">Player Aids</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="feelies">Feelies</link></style> are a type of <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style> that can be <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> without using the same medium as that which is used to let players have gameplay within a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>.

A design option related to how <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> provide information is if they give <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Direct%20Information">Direct</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Indirect%20Information">Indirect Information</link></style>. For example, <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style> can provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Indirect%20Information">Indirect Information</link></style> to the players on how to solve <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>, while <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> can allow players to deduce where <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> are located. Other <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> provide more <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Direct%20Information">Direct Information</link></style>, e.g. signs in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Oblivion">Oblivion</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda%20series">The Legend of Zelda series</link></style> that indicate directions where players can should go or explicit warn about dangers ahead.

While <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> are often passively waiting for players to find them, they can be used as part of <style="Link"><link="dynamic-difficulty-adjustment">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</link></style> systems to give hints when players have tried and failed with specific tasks several times. Having <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> appear as <style="Link"><link="tooltips">Tooltips</link></style> when players hover their <style="Link"><link="god-fingers">God Fingers</link></style> or their <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatar's</link></style> gaze long enough on game elements is another way in which games can activate <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> for players based on their behavior; <style="Link"><link="loading-hints">Loading Hints</link></style> can in contrast be used when one with good certainty wants to know that players will have seen them, at least if one has played a game sufficiently much.

<style="Link"><link="rabbit-hole-invitations">Rabbit Hole Invitations</link></style> are a special types of <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> which rather than provide hints on how to act within games are hints on how one can start playing a game.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> do not have to be diegetic since they relate to reaching gameplay goals, but making them fit with a game's <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> lets players use the facts about its <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Reality</link></style> to better understand the <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style>. They do need to do this if a game is supposed to have a <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structure</link></style> since not having this would provide perspectives other than that of the main protagonist. Specific parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> that can be used in this way include <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style>, as can <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> and other types of <style="Link"><link="information-passing">Information Passing</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> do not have to exist in <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>. They can also be presented within the interface or a game, e.g. as part of <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interfaces</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="mini">Mini-maps</link></style>, or larger maps in <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>. As an alternative, the <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> that exist in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> can be indicated in these interface components as well. The previously mentioned tooltips is another example of how <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> can be part of a game's interface rather than part of its <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>. These types of <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> are rather obviously <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> of a game.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

When <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> do not break <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> they can be part of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. Typically ways of combining the two patterns are through <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eavesdropping">Eavesdropping</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> are also quite commonly used to help solve <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> typically make <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> activities easier, and can be used to provide <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style> or focus players on what constitutes the core of <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>. As a more specific example, <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> related to <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> affects <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> while others make hint at where <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> exists in <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>. They are however <style="Link"><link="illusionary-rewards">Illusionary Rewards</link></style> since they in themselves do not affect game states in ways that help players. Even so, by explaining new actions or the characteristics of new game elements, <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> can help provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> throughout games, especially in the case where games provide more <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> as a form of <style="Link"><link="dynamic-difficulty-adjustment">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</link></style> to players progressing slowly. An example of this is the owl (a <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helper</link></style>) in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda:%20The%20Ocarina%20of%20Time">The Legend of Zelda: The Ocarina of Time</link></style> that sometimes flies in to steer players to the correct places.

Given players hints on what can be achieved, but also what can encountered, lets <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> provide both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> in games. <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> complying with a game's <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> can support <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structures</link></style> and let players use their understanding of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Reality</link></style> of a game to reason about the gameplay. When intertwine with <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, gaining <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> can become the goal objects of <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals, e.g. to learn about <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>.

Depending on how they are present and what information they contain, <style="CurrentLink">Clues</style> can either support <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> (and be modulated by it) or break it, e.g. through introducing <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> into a game. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style>, e.g. about how to use the game controls or the game mechanics, always gives rise to <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> and thereby break <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> and possibly also <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>.
